metadata.title: Highly active rhodium catalysts for the [2+2+2] cycloaddition of acetylenes

Compounds I - IV were very active in comparison with the isostructural cyclopentadienyl rhodium complexes. The catalytic activity depended markedly upon the nature of the substituents attached to the carbon-carbon triple bond, decreasing in the order: dimethyl acety lenedicarboxy late > methyl propi- olate > diphenylacetylene > 1-hexyne > 3-hexyne > 1-octyne. In almost all cases the reaction has shown a high chemoselectivity. Some influence of the nature of the cyclopentadienyl-like ligand on both the catalytic activity and the regioselectivity has been observed. By reacting diphenylacetylene (dpa) with roughly stoichiometric amounts of I and III, the complexes [Rh2(T?5-indenyl)2(dpa)2], (VI), and [Rh^-indenyl^i^-tetraphenylcyclobutadiene)], (VII), have been obtained, respectively. VI was poorly active and VII inactive in dpa cyclotrimerization. The mechanism of these cyclotrimerization reactions is discussed with reference to the role played by the indenyl and fluorenyl ligands in deter- mining the activity of the catalyst precursors I - IV. Introduction A wide variety of transition metal compounds act as catalysts for the cyclotrimerization of acetylenes to benzene derivatives [I], well-known examples being the Ziegler-type catalysts [2, 3] and a number of nickel(O) complexes [4-8]. Rhodium(I) complexes, in particular some cyclopentadienyl deriv- atives of the type [Rh^-CsRg^] (R = H or Me; L = CO, PPh3, etc.; *Authors to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/85/$3.30 Eisevier Sequoia/Printed in the Netherlands 182 L<2 = 1,5-cyclooctadiene), are poorly active or inactive [9-13]. One of the reasons for the poor activity of these catalyst precursors is probably the difficulty of the replacement of the L ligands by the alkyne [14,15]. Transition metal indenyl derivatives often exhibit higher reactivity, e.g. in ligand substitution reactions, than the corresponding isostructural cyclopentadienyl derivatives [16-20]. This difference has been explained on the basis of the postulated ability of the T^-indenyl ligand, unlike the parent cyclopentadienyl ligand, to undergo a facile bonding transformation from pentahapto to trihapto and vice-versa, thus liberating a coordination site for an entering ligand to be accommodated : MLn Tf -in deny I if -i ndenyI MLn The description of the T^-indenyl ligand in terms of 'coordinative flexibility' [21] can be extended to the fluorenyl ligand which, as has already been shown, can be bonded to transition metals in a variety of ways, including the ir-cyclopentadienyi (pentahapto) [19,21-25] and the Tr-allyl (trihapto) fashions [24]. These peculiarities make the indenyl and fluorenyl derivatives of transition metals particularly attractive for their potential interest as cata- lysts [18,19,26]. On this basis, we are studying the synthesis, reactivity and catalytic properties of a number of indenyl and fluorenyl derivatives of the cobalt triad metals [21, 27], and we describe below a detailed study of the cata- lytic properties of the rhodium(I) complexes I - IV in the cyclotrimeriza- tion of alkynes to benzene derivatives. (I), L = ethylene (II), L = eye Iooctene (III), L- 1,5-cyclooctadiene (IV) As will be disclosed, complexes I - IV exhibit in general a remarkable catalytic activity which, in the case of some substrates, is as high as that shown by the most active catalysts known until now. These findings not only substantiate the above predictions but, more interestingly, can also bring fresh perspectives to the design of very active new homogeneous transition metal catalysts. 183 Results and discussion For the present study we used the following internal and terminal acetylenes: dimethyl acetylenedicarboxylate (dma), 3-hexyne, diphenyl- acetylene (dpa), methyl propiolate (mp), 1-hexyne, 1-octyne, and phenyl- acetylene. For sake of clarity the results are discussed separately for each monomer. Internal alkynes Dma Table 1 reports some data concerning the oligomerization of the title compound with the complexes I - IV at temperatures ranging from 0 to 110 C (reaction time l h; [dma]/[Rh] molar ratio, 1000 or 2000). 'reaction time 8 h. ^-Xylene as solvent ; reaction time 9 h. 184 At 110 "C, all the catalyst precursors differ slightly from one another in catalytic activity, and give cyclotrimerization yields comparable with those obtained with the most active catalysts reported in the literature [1]. In particular, the activity of the compounds I - IV is, on the whole, much higher than that reported for cyclopentadienyl rhodium(I) derivatives [9 - 13], and higher than that observed by us using [Rh^-CsF^Hl.S-cyclo- octadiene)], (V), as catalyst precursor (Table 1). Interesting differences in the catalytic activity of I - IV are observed at low temperatures: I appears to be the only complex active at 0 C, while compounds II - IV become active only at 20 C; at these temperatures, I and IV are much more active than II and III. These facts may be related to the relatively facile olefinic ligand substitutions in I - IV by the reacting alkyne; in the indenyl complexes I - III ethylene is probably the most easily replace- able olefin, and a possible greater coordinative flexibility of the fluorenylic ligand makes cyclooctadiene more easily replaced in IV than in III. At higher temperatures, the differences in the facility of ligand substitution vanish and all complexes exhibit practically the same catalytic activity. 3-Hexyne The results obtained in the cyclotrimerization of 3-hexyne to hexa- ethylbenzene in the presence of I - IV, at 160 C, are reported in Table 2. The catalytic activity of I - IV is far lower than that observed in the case of dma cyclotrimerization. It is interesting to note that the complexes con- taining monodentate ligands (I and II) are more active than those (III and IV) containing 1,5-cyclooctadiene. ''l^^-trisicarbomethoxyibenzene; the complement to 100% is the 1,3,5-trisubstituted benzene isomer. 186 tions, but at higher reaction times (48 h) the yields increase to values which are comparable with the best figures obtained in the high temperature dma cyclotrimerization. High yields of tris(carbomethoxy)benzene (80 - 95% and 60-70% for [mp]/[Rh] molar ratios 1000 and 2000, respectively, were obtained at high reaction times (48 h) with all the complexes. A more differentiated behaviour of the catalyst precursors I - IV was observed at low reaction times (1 - 8 h), the complexes containing mono- dentate olefinic ligands (I and II) giving the highest yields. The cyclotrimerization of mp at temperatures ranging from 25 to 110 C (reaction time l h; [mp]/[Rh] molar ratio 1000 or 2000) has been also studied. Complexes III - V have been chosen as catalyst precursors in order to reveal the influence, if any, of the cyclopentadienyl-like ligand. The yields obtained with III and IV are plotted versus the reaction tem- perature in Fig. l. V does not show any activity in this temperature range. At higher temperatures III and IV give 60 - 70% and 50 - 60% yields for [mp]/[Rh] molar ratios 1000 and 2000, respectively, which are of the same order of magnitude as those obtained in the case of dma. At low temperatures (25 C) IV is more active than III, analogously to the behavior observed in the case of dma. 20 40 60 80 100 C Fig. l. In these cases the reaction mixture contains, in addition to cyclotrimers, substantial amounts of un- identified liquid products, presumably alkyne linear oligomers. The yield and composition of the cyclotrimers have been evaluated by GLC analysis of the crude reaction products, by adding calculated amounts of 1,2-diphenylethane in the case of 1-hexyne, and of triphenyl- methane in the case of 1-octyne, as quantitative internal standards (see Experimental). 187 TABLE 4 1-Hexyne and 1-octyne cyclotrimerization in the presence of complexes I - IV* Cat. "1,2,4-tri-n-butylbenzene and 1,2,4-tri-n-hexylbenzene, respectively; the complement to 100% is the 1,3,5-trisubstituted benzene isomer. The catalytic activities of I - IV are similar to those observed m 3- hexyne cyclotrimerization and far lower than those observed in the case of dma and mp cyclization. Moreover, m the case of 1-hexyne the indenylic complexes I - III give greater conversions than that observed using IV as catalyst; in contrast, in the case of 1-octyne, all complexes give comparable conversions. It is interesting to note that 1-hexyne furnishes mostly cyclo- trimers in the presence of the indenylic complexes I - III, while m the presence of the fluorenylic complex IV the linear oligomers are the major product; in contrast, in the case of 1-octyne all the complexes give a very poor yield of cyclotrimers with respect to the conversion. Phenylacetylene Tests of phenylacetylene cyclization with III and IV as catalyst pre- cursors at 50 C and a (phenylacetylene]/[Rh] molar ratio 500 have given polymeric products in 60% yield. A detailed study of this topic will be the subject of a subsequent paper. Regioselectivity In the case of the cyclotrimerization of monosubstituted alkynes, we have investigated the isomeric distribution of the resulting benzene deriva- tives. In all cases the mixture of cyclotrimers has been found to contain only the 1,3,5- and 1,2,4-tri-substituted benzenes. In the case of mp, the cyclotrimer composition has been evaluated by 'H NMR spectroscopy (see Experimental). The results are reported in Table 3. For all complexes the isomeric composition is almost independent 188 of the [mp]/[Rh] molar ratio and of the reaction time, and, with the flu- orenyl compound IV, the content of 1,3,5-trisubstituted benzene isomer is higher than that observed with the indenylic complexes I - III. The dif- ference in the isomeric distributions observed at 50 C with the indenylic and fluorenylic compounds is maintained with the variation of temperature, as is depicted in Fig. 2, where the amount of the 1,3,5-isomer (and 1,2,4- isomer) is plotted versus temperature. Also in this case the [mp]/[Rh] molar ratio does not influence the isomeric composition, but some depen- dence upon the temperature is observed with both the complexes examined, i.e. Ill and IV. In the case of 1-hexyne and 1-octyne, the isomeric distribution has been evaluated by GLC analysis (see Experimental): comparable cyclo- trimer distribution is obtained with all the catalytic complexes employed, the 1,3,5-isomer ranging from 29% to 32% in the case of 1-hexyne, and from 32% to 38% in the case of 1-octyne (see Table 4). 60 40 20 1,3,5-isomer % 40 20 40 60 80 100 Fig. 2. Isomeric composition of the tris(carbomethoxy)benzene as a function of tem- perature and catalyst. , III; , IV; o, [mp]/[Rh] molar ratio 2000; , [mp]/ [Rh] molar ratio 1000. Isolation of organometallic compounds We have investigated the possibility of intercepting complexes in these reactions, working at low temperature and low [alkyne]/[Rh] molar ratios in order to minimize the catalytic formation of cyclotrimers. We succeeded m isolating organometallic species only from the reactions of dpa with I and III. By reacting I with dpa ([dpa]/[Rh] molar ratio 10) at 25 or 80 C, it was possible to isolate, after column chromatography of the crude reaction mixture, a microcrystalline yellow compound to which the structure VI was attributed on the basis of the elemental analysis, and by ^ NMR and mass spectrometry. The 1!! NMR spectrum shows, in addition to the signals at o = 6.6 - 7.7 ppm due to the phenyl protons, two groups of resonances at o = 6.1 and 6.4 ppm and at o = 5.2 and 5.5 ppm attributed to the protons of the penta-atomic rings of the indenylic groups. These resonances are in keeping with the proposed structure containing two non-equivalent indenylic groups. Although the mass spectrum does not present the molecular ion, 189 the highest molecular weight peak is at m/e 574, which is consistent with the ion [Rh(Cgfi^(dpa)-i]* formed by fragmentation of VI. Complexes of this type are known [1, 10, 28, 29], and recently an analogous complex has been obtained by reacting I with 2-butyne [30]. (VII) III does not react with dpa at 25 C ([dpa]/[Rh] molar ratio 10); when carried out at 80 C this reaction allows isolation of, in addition to unreacted III, a microcrystalline yellow compound to which the structure VII has been attributed on the basis of the elemental analysis, 'H NMR and mass spectrometry. The 'H NMR spectrum shows, in addition to the intense signals at o = 6.8 - 7.8 ppm due to the phenyl protons, two weak signals at 6=6.6 and 5.7 ppm in the ratio 2/1 attributed to the protons of the penta-atomic ring of the indenylic group; the mass spectrum agrees with the proposed structure VII (molecular ion at m/e 574). Complexes of this type have been frequently isolated from the reaction of alkynes with transition metal compounds [31]. We have tested the role of these compounds in the catalytic reactions: VI exhibits poor activity (o-xylene, 140 C, 72 h), and VII is inactive (o- xylene, 160 C, 140 h) in the cyclotrimerization of dpa. These results are not surprising; indeed, it is known that cyclobutadiene metal complexes are not intermediates in the cyclotrimerization of alkynes, and further- more it has been shown that the appearance of compounds such as VI and VII during a catalytic process results in a decline in activity since their formation provides a very effective trap for the catalytically active species [1,30-34]. Concluding remarks This study shows that the indenyl and fluorenyl rhodium(I) com- plexes I - IV can act as efficient catalysts for the cyclotrimerization of alkynes containing electron-withdrawing or electron-donating substituents. The catalytic activity of these systems is exceptionally high when com- pared with that exhibited by the isostructural cyclopentadienyl rhodium(I) complexes. 190 Although the available experimental data do not provide direct evi- dence on the nature of the catalytic intermediates, it may be of interest to make some conjectures aimed at explaining how the presence of these ligands reflects on the activity. The discussion below is based on the assump- tion that all the intermediate metal species contain the fragments [Rh(cyclo- pentadienyl)], [Rh(indenyl)], or [Rh(fluorenyl)], and that the reaction mechanism (Scheme 1) involves, as is commonly accepted, the formation of a metallacyclopentadienic compound as a key step [1]. Even though these assumptions are essentially speculative, they are not without founda- tion, owing to a recent elegant study by Caddy et al. [19] on the reactivity of bis(ethylene)(i}5-indenyl)rhodium with acetylenes and the results obtained in the present work from the stoichiometric reactions of I and III with diphenylacetylene. CpRh'Lp 2L ,111 t .CpRh'^ ^ \in CpRI,- \111 CpRh CpRh^-k^ ' Scheme 1. Cp = T^-cyclopentadienyl, ^-indenyl, or T^-fluorenyl. Thus, on the basis of the proposed mechanism, we are inclined to consider chiefly two concepts as useful in interpreting how cyclopenta- dienyl, indenyl, and fluorenyl ligands influence the electronic environment at the active site. These concepts are the 'coordinative flexibility' and the 'electron donor-acceptor properties' of these ligands. As has been pointed out in the introduction, the first concerns the relative ease with which a pair of electrons can transfer to the ligand thus making available a vacant 191 orbital on the metal. Such electron transfer is made easier in the indenyl and fluorenyl ligands, due to the re-aromatization of benzo group, than in the cyclopentadienyl ligand [35]. As a consequence, the presence of indenyl and fluorenyl ligands could make the rhodium in all the intermediate species of the catalytic cycle able to accommodate an entering alkyne molecule within its coordination sphere via a relatively low activation energy process. On the other hand, since both the donor and acceptor properties of cyclopentadienyl (CsH5), indenyl (09117), and fluorenyl (C^Hc) ligands decrease in the order: CsH5 > CgR-, > C^Hg [36], rhodium(I) is less basic and rhodium(III) is more acid in the complexes with indenyl and fluorenyl ligands than these atoms are in their complexes with cyclopentadienyl ligands. As a consequence, the electron-accepting properties of rhodium(I) and rhodium(III) should be enhanced by the presence of indenyl and fluo- renyl ligands. This should favour the u-interaction of the entering alkyne molecule with both rhodium(I) and rhodium(III) atoms, and should in- crease the polarizing powers of these atoms to produce an amplification of the reactivity of coordinated alkyne, either in the oxidative cyclization step or in the insertion step. Experimental 'H NMR spectra were obtained on a Varian T60 instrument using Me4Si as internal standard. Mass spectra were obtained with a Varian MAT model CH7 spectrometer. GLC analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer F30 instrument equipped with flame ionization detectors. Melting or decom- position points were determined with a Kofler hot-stage apparatus and are uncorrected. Microanalyses were performed by the Laboratorio di Micro- analisi of the Istituto di Chimica Organica, Facolta di Farmacia, Universita di Pisa. Diethyl ether was refluxed and distilled from sodium and then from lithium aluminum hydride. Pentane, benzene, toluene, and o-xylene were washed free of olefins or thiophene with concentrated sulfuric acid, dried on calcium chloride and then distilled from lithium aluminum hydride. Unless otherwise noted, other solvents were reagent grade. Dimethyl acetylene- dicarboxylate, methyl propiolate and 1-hexyne (Fluka) were distilled under dinitrogen before use; 3-hexyne (Merck), 1-octyne and diphenylacetylene (Fluka) were used without further purification. (i^-Cyclopentadienyi)- (l,5-cyclooctadiene)rhodium(I) [37], (T}5-indenyl)bis(ethylene)rhodium(I) [19], (T^-indeny^bis^yclooctene^hodiun^I) [27], (i^-indenyl^l.o-cyclo- octadiene)rhodium(I) [27] and (i^-fluorenylXl^-cyclooctadiene^hodiumtI) [27] were prepared as described. General procedure for cyclotrimerization reactions The cyclotrimerization reactions were carried out under dinitrogen atmosphere in a Schlenk or sealed tube. Benzene, toluene or o-xylene can 192 be used indifferently as solvents, the choice being based upon the reaction temperature. The reaction mixtures were made by adding the freshly pre- pared catalyst solution to the solution of acetylenic compound, and they were kept at the reaction temperature with a thermostatted oil bath ( 0.2 C). At the end of the experiment the catalyst was destroyed by the addi- tion of a few crystals of iodine, and the solvent was removed under vacuum. The isolation and characterization of the products were performed as de- scribed in the following illustrative procedures. Cyclotrimerization of dimethyl acetylenedicarboxylate (dma) Dma (1 ml, 8.14 mmol), introduced in a Schlenk tube containing benzene (20 ml), was reacted with IV (8.09 X 10~3 mmol; 0.46 ml of a 1.76X10"2 M benzene solution). The resulting solution was stirred at 50 C for l h and then a few crystals of I; were added. After cooling at room temperature, the solvent and the unreacted dma were removed under reduced pressure. The residue was washed with pentane (3 X 20 ml), and dried under vacuum. 0.937 g of crude hexamethyl mellitate (81% yield) were obtained. Recrystallization from methanoi solutions gave white crystals of hexamethyl mellitate having m.p. 185 - 186 C (lit. [38] 189 C); the 'H NMR spectrum in CgD^ consisted of a singlet at 6 3.20 ppm (CH3). Cyclotrimerization of methyl propiolate (mp) To a solution of methyl propiolate (1 ml, 11.97 mmol) in benzene (20 ml), IV (11.97 X lO"3 mmol; 2.48 ml of a 0.483 X 10"2 M benzene solution) was added. The resulting solution was stirred at 50 C for l h and then a few crystals of 1^ were added. After cooling to room temperature, the solvent and the unreacted mp were removed under reduced pressure. The residue (0.126 g) was dissolved in methanoi and the resulting solution was cooled to 30 C to give l,3,5-tris(carbomethoxy)benzene having m.p. 144 C (lit. [39] 146 C). The H NMR spectrum in CD^COCD^ consisted of two singlets at 0 4.00 ppm (9H) and o 8.70 ppm (3H) due to the methyl and phenyl protons, respectively. The mother liquors, dried under vacuum, gave a residue which, by crystallization from pentane at 30 C, furnished l,2,4-tris(carbomethoxy)benzene having m.p. 96 C (lit. [5] 96 - 99 C). 'H NMR spectrum (CDaCOCDa): 5=3.89-3.95 (m, 9H, CH3), 7.82 (d, 1H, He; ^(He-Hs) = 8 Hz), 8.23 (dd, 1H, Hs; ^(Hs-Ha) = 2 Hz), 8.36 (d, 1H, Ha) ppm. The isomeric distribution of products formed from different reactions was routinely evaluated by ^ NMR spectroscopy on the basis of the relative intensities of the signals at o 8.70 ppm (1,3,5-isomer) and at 8 7.82, 8.23 and 8.36 ppm (1,2,4-isomer). Cyclotrimerization of 3-hexyne A sealed glass tube containing o-xylene (10 ml), 3-hexyne (1 ml, 8.82 mmol) and IV (0.0352 mmol; 1.3 ml of a 2.71 X 10~2 M o-xylene solution) ( [3-hexyne]/[Rh] molar ratio 250) was heated at 150 C for 85 h, and then 193 the solvent and the unreacted alkyne were removed under reduced pres- sure. The resulting orange residue was dissolved in CCl4 (2 ml) and chro- matographed'on a column of neutral alumina (0 1.5 cm, h 10 cm) using pentane as eluant. The collected solution (70 ml) was evaporated to dryness to give white crystals of hexaethylbenzene (0.076 g, 11% yield) having m.p. 126 "C (lit. [3] 129 C). The 'H NMR spectrum in CCL consisted of two resonances at o 1.18 (t, 18 H) and at 5 2.60 (q, 12 H;J(H H) = 8 Hz) ppm assignable to the methyl and methylene protons respectively. Cyclotrimerization of 1-hexyne A sealed glass tube containing o-xylene (10 ml), 1-hexyne (1 ml, 8.72 mmol), and IV (0.0347 mmol; 1.28 ml of a 2.71 X 10~2 M o-xylene solution) ([ 1-hexyne]/[Rh] molar ratio 250) was heated at 150 C for 93 h, and the solvent and the unreacted alkyne were then removed under reduced pres- sure. The resulting oily residue (0.191 g) was dissolved in CCl4 (2 ml) and 1,2-diphenylethane (0.204 mmol; 0.5 ml of a 0.408 M CC4 solution) was added as internal standard. This solution was then quantitatively analyzed by GLC on a 2 m Carbowax column under the following conditions: column temperature, 170 C; inlet temperature, 250 C; dinitrogen gas speed, 12 ml min"1. The chromatogram revealed, besides the solvent and the added internal standard, the presence of the 1,3,5- and 1,2,4-tri-n-butylbenzene by comparison with authentic samples. By evaluating the internal standard peak area and those of the two benzene isomers, the yield of cyclotrimers (4%) and the isomeric composition were calculated (1,3,5-tri-n-butylben- zene, 31%; 1,2,4-tri-n-butylbenzene, 69%). Cyclotrimerization of 1-octyne A sealed glass tube containing o-xylene (10 ml), 1-octyne (1 ml, 6.78 mmol) and IV (0.0271 mmol; 2.1 ml of a 1.29 X lO"2 M o-xylene solution )- ([l-octyne]/[Rh] molar ratio 250) was heated at 160 C for 119 h, and the solvent and the unreacted alkyne were then removed under reduced pres- sure. The resulting oily residue (0.349 g, 47% conversion of 1-octyne) was dissolved in CCl4 (3 ml), and triphenylmethane (0.143 mmol; 1 ml of a 0.143 M CCl4 solution) was added as internal standard. Then this solution was quantitatively analyzed by GLC on a 2 m Carbowax column (column temperature 190 C; inlet temperature 300 C; dinitrogen gas speed, 18 ml min"1). In addition to the solvent and the added internal standard, the chromatogram revealed the presence of 1,3,5- and 1,2,4-tri-n-hexylbenzene, identified by comparison of their retention times with those of authentic samples. By the evaluation of the internal standard peak area and that of the two benzene isomers, the yield of cyclotrimers (5%) and the isomeric composition (1,3,5-tri-n-hexylbenzene, 38%; 1,2,4-tri-n-hexylbenzene, 62%) were calculated. Cyclotrimerization of diphenylacetylene (dpa) A Schlenk tube containing o-xylene (10 ml), dpa (l g, 5.61 mmol) and IV (0.0224 mmol; 1.74 ml of a 1.29 X 10~2 M o-xylene solution; 194 [dpa]/[Rh] molar ratio 250) was heated at 100 C for 46 h. White crystals of hexaphenylbenzene (0.179 g, 14% yield) formed which were washed with diethyl ether (3 X 20 ml) and dried under vacuum. M. W. 534 (mass spectrum). Anal. found: C 94.25, H 5.55%; C^ii^o calculated: C 94.34; H 5.66%. Reaction between I and dpa A mixture of dpa (1.116 g, 6.27 mmol) and I (0.172 g, 0.627 mmol) in benzene (10 ml) was stirred at room temperature for 62 h, and the solvent then removed under vacuum. The residue was dissolved in pentane (10 ml) and the resulting solution was chromatographed on a column of neutral alumina (0 1.5 cm, h 30 cm) using pentane as eluant until the unreacted dpa was completely eliminated. At this point the elution was continued, using a 1:10 mixture of diethyl ether and pentane, and a yellow band was collected which furnished a poor yield of yellow crystals to which the structure VI was attributed. Anal. found: C 68.95, H 4.99%; C^H^Rh^ calculated: C 69.70, H 4.32%. MS: m/e = 574 (25); 534 (3); 459 (7); 396 (7);356 (5);281 (10); 218 (100);178 (43); 115(57); 103(23). Reaction between III and dpa A mixture of o-xylene (10 ml),, dpa (0.86 g, 4.83 mmol) and III (0.157 g, 0.483 mmol) was heated at 80 C for 20 h; hexaphenylbenzene subse- quently precipitated and was separated by decantation (0.555 g, 65% yield). The solution was evaporated to dryness, and the oily residue was dissolved in pentane (10 ml). The resulting solution was chromatographed on a col- umn of neutral alumina (Merck, 0 1.5 cm, h 30 cm), using pentane as eluant until the unreacted dpa was completely eliminated. The elution was continued using a 1:10 mixture of diethyl ether and pentane, and a yellow band was collected that furnished yellow crystals of unreacted III. The elution was then continued with a 1:1 mixture of diethyl ether and pentane, and a further yellow band was collected that gave VII (15% yield) by evapo- ration of the solvent under reduced pressure. Anal. found: C 78.73, H 5.19%; C37H27Rh calculated: C 77.30, H 4.70%. MS: m/e = 574 (100); 534 (7); 459 (21); 396 (9); 356 (4); 281 (20); 218 (66); 178 (44); 115 (19);103(22). X244 85800262 0304-5102(85)80026-2 10.1016/0304-5102(85)80026-2 Chemical catalysis Highly active rhodium catalysts for the [2+2+2] cycloaddition of acetylenes Angelo Borrini Pietro Diviersi Giovanni Ingrosso 1 Antonio Lucherini 1 Giorgio Serra Istituto di Chimica Organica Industriale, Università di Pisa, Via Risorgimento 35, 56100 PisaItaly 1 Authors to whom correspondence should be addressed. The catalytic activity of the complexes [Rh(π5-indenyl)L2] (L = ethylene or cyclooctene; L2 = 1,5-cyclooctadiene), (I) - (III), and [Rh(π5-fluorenyl) (1,5-cyclooctadiene)], (IV), in the cyclotrimerization reaction of alkynes to benzene derivatives has been investigated. Compounds I - IV were very active in comparison with the isostructural cyclopentadienyl rhodium complexes. The catalytic activity depended markedly upon the nature of the substituents attached to the carbon-carbon triple bond, decreasing in the order: dimethyl acetylenedicarboxylate > methyl propiolate > diphenylacetylene > 1-hexyne > 3-hexyne > 1-octyne. In almost all cases the reaction has shown a high chemoselectivity. Some influence of the nature of the cyclopentadienyl-like ligand on both the catalytic activity and the regioselectivity has been observed. By reacting diphenylacetylene (dpa) with roughly stoichiometric amounts of I and III, the complexes [Rh2π5-indenyl)2(dpa)2], (VI), and [Rh(π5-indenyl)(π4-tetraphenylcyclobutadiene)], (VII), have been obtained, respectively. VI was poorly active and VII inactive in dpa cyclotrimerization. The mechanism of these cyclotrimerization reactions is discussed with reference to the role played by the indenyl and fluorenyl ligands in determining the activity of the catalyst precursors I - IV. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic activity of the complexes [Rh(π5-indenyl)L2] (L = ethylene or cyclooctene; L2 = 1,5-cyclooctadiene), (I) - (III), and [Rh(π5-fluorenyl) (1,5-cyclooctadiene)], (IV), in the cyclotrimerization reaction of alkynes to benzene derivatives has been investigated. Compounds I - IV were very active in comparison with the isostructural cyclopentadienyl rhodium complexes. The catalytic activity depended markedly upon the nature of the substituents attached to the carbon-carbon triple bond, decreasing in the order: dimethyl acetylenedicarboxylate > methyl propiolate > diphenylacetylene > 1-hexyne > 3-hexyne > 1-octyne. In almost all cases the reaction has shown a high chemoselectivity. Some influence of the nature of the cyclopentadienyl-like ligand on both the catalytic activity and the regioselectivity has been observed. By reacting diphenylacetylene (dpa) with roughly stoichiometric amounts of I and III, the complexes [Rh2π5-indenyl)2(dpa)2], (VI), and [Rh(π5-indenyl)(π4-tetraphenylcyclobutadiene)], (VII), have been obtained, respectively. VI was poorly active and VII inactive in dpa cyclotrimerization. The mechanism of these cyclotrimerization reactions is discussed with reference to the role played by the indenyl and fluorenyl ligands in determining the activity of the catalyst precursors I - IV.
coredata.dc:title: Highly active rhodium catalysts for the [2+2+2] cycloaddition of acetylenes
